Field.Value: In the year 1718 the land of Khazystan found itself at the end of an era of peace and prosperity. As winter closed in around them the people themselves grew cold. The Tzar had fallen ill, and lay on his deathbed. The governor of one of his large cities had taken command, and was imposing new rules to keep the peace. But not everyone was fond of these orders…

Field.Value: After their first victory, the newly formed rebellion spent little time celebrating. They enjoyed only one night in the city before Brezhnev had them formed up and ready to move. For the next week he trained them, from peasants to soldiers, and then he set his sights on the Tzar and the capital. But what he found in the fields, was an ambush.

Field.Value: Pressing on, Brendan and his rebellion arrive outside the capitol, where he is confronted by the Governess’ forces, yet again. The remnants of her guard and other militia she gathered in the last two weeks gather themselves outside the city gates, while the Governess looks on from high up on the walls.

Field.Value: I see you've made it inside the city. I'll bet you're weary, perhaps you want to see an inn? It's unfortunate you'll find no hospitality here.

Field.Value: Aye, you’re right. I have grown weary. The Tzar’s rule has taken its toll. It’s about time for some change, don’t you think?

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value: It’s not your hospitality I want, it’s the city. It will be mine, and the Tzar will fall.

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value: I won’t let you take the city, outlaw. My order, the Tzar’s order, is absolute. We are building a perfect world. We’re so close. I won’t let you tear down all that I have built.

Field.Hint: The text that is displayd to the player in a list as a dialogue option.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value: On that day, Brezhnevstormed the castle, and slew the Tzar in his bed. The Tzar had been ill and feeble. Another week and the fever may have done the job on its own. Nonetheless, Brezhnev kept to his word and destroyed the remnants of the government. His ragtag army looted the city then dispersed. In short order the world fell to chaos without any leader. Brezhnev kept to himself, living in the stone fort of his hometown.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value: On that day, Brezhnevstormed the castle, and slew the Tzar in his bed. The Tzar had been ill and feeble. Another week and the fever may have done the job on its own. Nonetheless, Brezhnev kept to his word and took the castle for himself. He named himself Tzar, and the people cheered him on. He dreamed of a government that did not oppress its people, so he gave his officers every privilege. But between his zealous rage, and his officers lusts, they had become the very monster they set out to destroy.
